GPS on wheels
Project homepage

GPS on Wheels - A Robotics-Project at the IWR in Heidelberg

This winter term we're doing an interesting internship at our university: We're constructing a robotic RC-car, supplied with a Rasperry Pi-Computer and a GPS-module in order to be able to drive autonomously.
The internship started in October 2014 already and lasts until the end of March approximately.


The university

The internship takes place at the University of Heidelberg, a small, but famous and beautiful town in the south of Germany. The university can proudly call itself the oldest one in Germany.
Altough all of us are studying physics, the project is part of the Informatics Faculty, which illustrates the flexibility in our studies and also gives a hint of what we're mainly doing here: programming.


The goals

The main goal is to construct and configure an autonomous RC-car, which should be able to reach a given GPS-Position somewhere nearby, avoiding small obstacles.
Thus it is part of the project to supply a RC-car with a small computer (Raspberry-Pi), a GPS-module and some sensors to detect obstacles. Of course, also the programming of the components -as they need to work together- makes a great part of it.
Some milestones can be summarized as follows:

  • choosing appropriate components (RC-car construction-kit, batteries, motor, Raspberry Pi, ultra-sonic sensors, GPS-module ...)
  • constructing the RC-car out of the construction-kit, attach batteries, motor & cruise control
  • modifying the car by attaching the Raspberry Pi, as well as the sensors & the GPS-module;
    herefore: adding a platform onto which the components can be put
  • connecting all components in a safe way
  • constructing some cover for the electronics to be safe from dirt, moisture etc.
  • developing some algorithm of how everything works together
  • programming a lot of routines for the different needs (getting GPS-position, calculating target-position & direction, getting sensor-data, recognizing obstacles, driving the car, avoiding obstacles, finding a good way, handling errors...)
  • testing, impoving, testing, improving....

Besides these practicle things, of course it is a declared goal to improve our skills and to learn about informatics during this internship. Apart from programming, the project also involves a lot of (electronical) handicraft. We therefore get in touch with electric circuits, information processing, mechanics and the interplay of hard- and software.

As we will have to face many problems, we will have to learn to react and find solutions flexibly.
